incident_updates.body: We are working on resolving some internal technical problems now.
Discord is affected by the general internet outage. Hang tight.  Pet your cats.
This incident has been resolved.
We have fixed the underlying issue but recovery of the Push service will take another 30-60 minutes.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
Google reports the situation has been resolved. If you are still seeing issues, let us know!
Google continues to work on mitigating the issue and expects to see improvement soon. Discord staff is still standing by, monitoring the situation.
Google has identified the issue and is working on it.

Google Cloud is currently having an issue with their networking. This is affecting many web sites, including Discord, and there is unfortunately nothing we can do at this time. Google is working on it and we are standing by to take any actions on our end that might become necessary, but until then, our best advice is to hang tight and we're sorry for the inconvenience!

This incident is primarily impacting users in the northeastern part of the North American continent, but due to the vagaries of Internet routing, is also impacting some western European users.
Service has returned to normal operation.
Remediations have been deployed and service has returned to normal operations.  The oncall engineering team will continue to monitor the service to ensure its recovery.

Throughout the day our oncall engineers have been investigating an ongoing issue with one of our underlaying data stores that is causing intermittent latency issues and message send failures.

The oncall engineers have identified a workload that has caused degraded performance with one of our Cassandra nodes and are deploying remediations to restore the service to normal operation.

incidents.name: Sporadic Issues with Latency and Sending Messages

incident_updates.body: We have expanded the database cluster and believe everything is back to normal.

We are aware of some ongoing/sporadic issues with latency and sending messages. We believe we have identified the cause and are working to expand our MongoDB cluster in order to provide some breathing room.
This incident has been resolved.
We are currently investigating this issue.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

Things look good and we believe the system has recovered fully.

We did take some actions to prevent this from recurring, notably expanding our gateway cluster, and we learned some things regarding Postgres' ability to be in the hot path of logins. We will be investigating these this coming week to continue to make improvements to the stability and resilience of Discord.

Thank you for your patience today, and good luck with the gaming!
We have fully released the ravens and removed all of the limits. Discord should be functioning normally but we are keeping an eye on it.

We identified an issue with our gateway cluster. It ran out of memory and crashed, resetting everybody's connection. We are having to rate limit logins to protect the underlying databases and bring Discord back up in a healthy fashion.

This means that logins will be slow for now while we continue to work to raise the threshold back to 100%, please bear with us.
We are aware of an issue disconnecting some users and making Discord slow to send messages. We are online and investigating.

incidents.name: Trouble logging in and sending messages

incident_updates.body: The incident has been resolved and the service is completely restored.
We identified one of our Mongos that demonstrated instability. We killed long running queries and the service is recovering now. We are monitoring.
Hello, the team is online and investigating reports of slowness.

incidents.name: DMs delayed and Online friends missing for some users

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
Still seeing issues, we are investigating again.

incidents.name: DMs delayed and Online friends missing for some users

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are currently investigating this issue.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently investigating this issue.

incidents.name: Increased Error Rate and Latency for API

incident_updates.body:
We've rolled out fixes that should address the platform instability. We observed a few interesting failure modes here, and have rolled out mitigations for each of them - however the root cause of the initial failures are still under investigation. 

Discord runs a cluster of redis nodes which we use for caching of stuff, namely push notification settings and partial user objects. This cache cluster sees a throughput of peak in the order multi-million queries per second to power Discord. During peak hours today and throughout the past few hours, throughput on 4 of our cache nodes dropped, and continued to stay in a degraded state. We ejected some cache nodes from the cluster in an attempt to remediate the issue, however, after ejecting 2 and continuing to observe similar failures on other nodes, we decided not to continue to eject nodes, as a continued reduction in cache-cluster availability would have more adversely affected service availability. 

Generally, when a cache node is degraded, or unavailable, we have circuit breakers in place which degrade low-priority tasks while preserving platform availability. However, there was a bug in our circuit breaking code, and 2 bugs in the downstreams of the circuit-breaker that caused a thundering herd on our upstream data-store of these objects (mongodb), causing it to become overloaded and flap in availability. We've since deployed fixes to our API service layer to prevent the thundering herd issue that adversely affected platform stability.

We are still however observing issues with our cache nodes that still causing intermittent blips - however - hopefully those blips should not net in service disruption/degraded performance. In concert, we are investigating the root cause of the redis node throughput issues with the Google Cloud Platform team.
Service is restored, engineers are working to address the root cause of the failure.
Root cause has been identified and remediations are being applied
Engineers are actively responding and restoring service.
We are currently investigating an increased error rate and latency for API Requests

incidents.name: Users unable to connect to Discord.

incident_updates.body:
We still have one database machine that is offline intentionally at this point. We are waiting until we're off of peak traffic before turning it back online. We have also disabled some internal functionality that is not user impacting in order to shed load from the databases.

We're going to mark this incident as resolved as the user impact is complete and, pending another incident, we do not expect it to recur.

We are continuing to see impact to one of our MongoDB machines which is causing the recovery to be slow and is what kicked off this problem. Google has confirmed this is a problem with their storage layer and they are escalating internally to try to achieve resolution.

Separately, we have identified some slowness being caused by a recent change we made to migrate data out of MongoDB and into Postgres. We have overloaded the Postgres setup and it is responding slowly. We are expanding that datababase now to provide more breathing room.

The service should be nearly recovered. We are still monitoring some additional latency causing message sends to be a little slower than usual, but this should clear up as the database caches warm up.

We will be investigating the root cause as well as working to understand why recovery took so long. We'll post another update when the incident is resolved, or if we have further information.
We have resolved the issue and are letting people back in slowly.
We are aware of the issue and trying to resolve it.
We are looking into why users cannot connect to Discord. Connected users should be fine.
Service has been restored and is stable.
Connection and API issues are resolved. We are monitoring and will update soon.
We are currently investigating this issue.
This incident has been resolved via multiple mitigations.
We've added more capacity to some systems and are working on fixing some remaining slowness.

Discord is working well right now. We continue to work on adding capacity to a couple of systems that are exhibiting signs of load. We are leaving this incident open while we continue to add capacity to these systems and monitor for a decrease in load.
We've identified some slowness in our Redis caching cluster and are working to expand the cluster at this time.
We are aware of some slowness while connecting to and interacting with the Discord service. The team is online and investigating.

We're marking this incident as resolved because the current issue is past and we've performed remediation on the involved cluster.

However, the underlying root cause is still being investigated. We can say that this is the same thing that has happened a couple of times now -- we're seeing runaway memory utilization on a few sessions servers which leads to them running out of memory. This causes a handful to crash, which forces users to reconnect on the remaining servers -- sometimes forcing them into an out of memory case as well. In the worst instances of this behavior, this cascades to the entire cluster.

We currently have a lot of data and a couple hypotheses, but we're still working to fully understand the root cause. Once we do we'll write up a postmortem. Given the number of times this has happened in the past month, we are treating this as an important issue and putting a lot of the team on understanding what has happened and how to properly resolve it for the long-term.

We are continuing to investigate the root cause and work through remediating the sessions machines with low remaining memory. We will update again when we have more information, but the service is at the moment stable.
We continue to see issues with sending direct messages and seeing the online status of your friends. We are still working on the issue.
We've identified an issue affecting our sessions service. We are taking action to remediate the problem.
We are aware of an incident affecting connecting to Discord and sending messages for some users. The team is online and investigating.
The issue has been resolved and service is restored.
We have identified a regional connection issue affecting a subset of users, engineering is working to resolve this issue.

incidents.name: Some Slowness + Private Calls are Sometimes Failing

incident_updates.body: Discord is back to normal and everything should be working again.
We have identified an issue causing Discord to be a little slow and private calls (in direct messages/groups) to fail. We're rolling out a fix now.
We've confirmed that all previous connection issues have been resolved. We apologize for any inconvenience.
We're aware that these connection issues may be affecting users outside of Finland and are continuing to investigate.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.

We're seeing an elevated rate of errors and user reports describing connection errors when connecting. We're currently investigating and working with our upstream providers to diagnose and resolve this issue.

The image resizing service has been successfully resurrected. Images that failed to load in the past should load again with a restart of the client.

The cluster got itself into a metastable failure-state due to a service discovery mechanism getting overloaded due to a new workload we've introduced onto the cluster in the past month. A deploy to fix a bug tripped it up. We've modified configurations to make this not happen, and will be taking appropriate measures over the next week to ensure that such an issue does not recur. 

We apologize for any inconvenience this has caused!
This issue will also affect icons throughout the application as we recover our image resizing service.
We are aware of issues with the attachment image previews not working - and are working on a fix currently.

The issue has been identified and we are working on fixing it.
This incident has been resolved.

incidents.name: Increased API Latency & Failed Message Sends

incident_updates.body: The secondary that previously failed has successfully snuggled up near a warm fire with a cozy blanket and some hot cocoa and is now adequately warm to serve traffic at nominal latency.
The secondary appears to be sufficiently warm now, and we are noticing error rates and latency drop to nominal levels.

We are aware of issues regarding higher than normal latency, and failed message sends. The team is aware of the root cause of the issue (a host error on one of our database secondaries caused it to reboot). 

During this time, the secondary is "cold" as it loads data into memory. We are monitoring the instance as it warms up, and expect latency to fully recover in 5-15 minutes, and latency to continue to as the secondary gradually warms up.

We're good again. Additional configuration changes have been made to hopefully reduce the likelihood of this happening again. 

We believe this issue to be unrelated to the earlier issues, even though the end-user effect is the same. Essentially, GCP decided to migrate 50% of the cluster at the same time, causing a large dip in throughput and causing the cluster to degrade and require manual intervention.

We're having a slight struggle again with DMs and Friends Lists. 

Our team is online and working on the issue.

Service recovery is complete, and the cluster has been scaled up. We hopefully don't expect this issue to recur after this. 

Apologies again for all the inconvenience!
Additional capacity has been added and we've rebooted the service. Service recovery is underway and is expected to complete momentarily.
We're investigating similar crash as yesterday, and are restarting the service. Additionally, we are adding more capacity to the service, as we think the crash is load-based.

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We're aware of an issue where DMs are not being updated in real time and are working on a fix.

Discord is stable for a while now and all ancillary services have recovered. We don't anticipate a recurrence of this problem at this time (and if it does, we know how to recover it much more quickly now).

The root cause is still not entirely clear. We've seen seeing a lot of Google Cloud related migrations and TCP retransmits this morning, but the bulk of the issue today was caused when our primary MongoDB got into a bad state and was failing to serve traffic effectively. We had to perform some heavy load shedding to enable it to recover and get back to normal.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.
The issues with our MongoDB have been addressed and we believe everything is returning to normal.
We're aware of more issues, and are investigating.
We're aware of more issues, and are investigating.
Service is recovered, and our team is still investigating the causes of this issue.
We're aware of continued issues with the service and are investigating.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.

We believe the blips to be caused by a network failure within google cloud platform. Our team is working to get more details, however, for now, the issue appears to have only been from 11:03 to 11:13 AM PDT.
We are investigating some connection and latency issues. The team is online and investigating, we will update when we know more.
